001package net.tvburger.jdl.model;
002
003import net.tvburger.jdl.common.patterns.DomainObject;
004import net.tvburger.jdl.common.patterns.Strategy;
005
006/**
007 * The {@link #estimate(float[])} method defines the contract for mapping input values
008 * to output values according to a specific estimation algorithm.
009 * Different implementations may use linear, non-linear, or domain-specific (symbolic AI) logic.
010 */
011@DomainObject
012@Strategy(Strategy.Role.INTERFACE)
013public interface EstimationFunction {
014
015    /**
016     * Applies the estimation algorithm to the given input vector.
017     *
018     * @param inputs an array of input values (e.g., features, signals)
019     * @return an array of output values computed by the estimation function
020     */
021    float[] estimate(float[] inputs);
022
023    /**
024     * Returns the <b>arity</b> of this function, i.e. the number of inputs
025     * (independent variables or features) it expects.
026     * <p>
027     * For example:
028     * <ul>
029     *   <li>A univariate function {@code f(x)} has arity 1.</li>
030     *   <li>A multivariate function {@code f(x, y, z)} has arity 3.</li>
031     *   <li>In machine learning, this corresponds to the input feature dimension.</li>
032     * </ul>
033     *
034     * @return the number of inputs (arity) this function accepts
035     */
036    int arity();
037
038
039    /**
040     * Returns the <b>co-arity</b> of this function, i.e. the number of outputs
041     * (dependent variables or results) it produces.
042     * <p>
043     * For example:
044     * <ul>
045     *   <li>A scalar-valued function {@code f(x, y)} → ℝ has co-arity 1.</li>
046     *   <li>A vector-valued function {@code f(x, y)} → ℝ² has co-arity 2.</li>
047     *   <li>In machine learning, this corresponds to the output dimension
048     *       (e.g., number of labels or regression targets).</li>
049     * </ul>
050     *
051     * @return the number of outputs (co-arity) this function produces
052     */
053    int coArity();
054
055}
